Dear Mrs. Fernandez:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 For repeat violations, why the prior CAP did not result in compliance.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
A first provisional license is recommended. If you do not contest the issuance of a
provisional license, you must indicate so in writing on the attached document. If you
contest the issuance of a provisional license, you must notify this office in writing and an
administrative hearing will be scheduled. Even if you contest the issuance of a
provisional license, you must still submit an acceptable corrective action plan.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract. Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me
with any questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to

ALLEGATION:
On 11/16/21, three youths went AWOL from the facility and stole a car they found
unlocked on the grounds. Youths A and B AWOL on a regular basis.
INVESTIGATION:
Methodist Children’s Home is a 60-bed campus-based residential treatment facility
with 10 beds designated for short-term shelter. The three youths involved were
housed in the shelter program prior to going AWOL per Methodist’s internal census
data. Methodist does not seclude youth. The use of seclusion requires written
approval from the department’s licensing authority, which Methodist has not
requested. Per Methodist’s written restraint policy, physical restraint is not permitted
to prevent escape or truancy.
Youth A
A report by Therapist 1 dated 11/17/21 summarized Youth A’s current functioning
and history prior to placement at Methodist. In Nov 2020, he reportedly assaulted
his adoptive mother and was placed in a detention facility. When his mother refused
to accept him back into her home in Feb 2021, Youth A was placed in the care of
MDHHS. He remained in detention until April 2021 at which time he was placed at a
residential treatment facility. In Aug 2021, that treatment facility requested he be
removed due to AWOLs, property destruction, aggressive behaviors, and
auditory/visual hallucinations. Youth A was then psychiatrically hospitalized for two
months and then placed in Methodist’s short-term shelter on 10/9/21.
Since his placement at the shelter, Youth A’s behaviors of going AWOL, physically
intimidating, and becoming aggressive toward peers and staff reportedly continued.
According to Chief Administrator 1, Youth A went AWOL from Methodist 11 times in
5 weeks.
I reviewed an individualized safety plan for Youth A authored by Therapist 1
developed on 10/13/21 and updated on 11/2/21. The plan identified verbal and non-
verbal cues to warn staff that Youth A is “escalating”. Some identified cues are a
loss of affect, intimidating female staff, trying to take staff’s phone or keys, becoming
3

quiet or loud, cursing and destroying property. Staff interventions when Youth A is
experiencing auditory or visual hallucinations include maintaining line of sight, verbal
redirection, speaking in low tones, and telling Youth A the visions and sounds can’t
hurt him. A cue specific to going AWOL is noticing when a peer or peers encourage
him to AWOL. If a peer encourages him to AWOL, staff are to separate him from
that peer by engaging him in an activity and watching him closely in the back of the
cottage as he often leaves out the back door. If Youth A leaves the cottage, staff are
to follow him. If he leaves the campus or line of sight, staff are to retrieve a vehicle
and canvas the area. If unable to locate him, staff are to file a police report and
contact the appropriate parties.
Youth A is currently prescribed three different psychotropic medications and
described as having a “fixation on guns and weapons” and pretends to “shoot
people.” Youth A reportedly is in special education for autism and uses nicotine,
marijuana, and alcohol.
On 11/18/21, I interviewed Youth A, age 13, jointly with Government Worker 1.
Physically, he is bigger than average for his age. Youth A presented as cognitively
impaired.
When asked about the events on 11/16/21, Youth A was unable to tell a sensible
story in a logical sequence. Records indicate he and Youth B walked off campus
together without permission on 11/16/21 at 4pm and then Youth A returned to his
cottage alone the next morning at 6:45am.
Youth A was unable to accurately estimate the passage of time. He referred to this
particular AWOL as happening last night, Monday night and three weeks ago. He
could not explain where or when Youths A, B and C met up after leaving the campus
separately. At some point, Youth A said he rode on a bus and in a car. Youth A
said Youth B checked the doors of some parked cars and found that one was
unlocked. It is unclear if Youth A witnessed this or if someone told him this
happened. Youth A said “Youth B was driving…We hopped in…He drove to his
dad’s house. His dad said, ‘go back’…There were four of us.” Somewhere along
the way, he said a fourth youth from the community joined the three boys from
Methodist. Youth A was unwilling or unable to indicate where or when the fourth
youth joined them and did not provide the identity of that youth.
Youth B
A report by Therapist 1 dated 11/15/21 indicated that prior to his placement at
Methodist on 9/29/21, Youth B was psychiatrically hospitalized in June 2021,
prescribed two psychotropic medications, and had a history of going AWOL,
destroying property, and engaging in risky behaviors. During his 7-week stay at
Methodist, records indicate Youth B went AWOL 11 times.
4

I reviewed an individualized safety plan for Youth B authored by Therapist 1
developed on 10/2/21 and updated on 11/2/21. The plan identified verbal and non-
verbal cues to warn staff he is “escalating.” Some identified cues are pacing, balling
fists, destroying property, walking out the front door, cursing and arguing. Patterns
and cues specific to going AWOL were Youth B feeling unhappy he was removed
from his father, and he was known to prefer leaving the campus with others, would
ask the whereabouts of peers and when they’d return. Staff interventions when
Youth B is “escalated” are to maintain line of sight of Youth B at all times except in
the bathroom or shower. Interventions specific to AWOL are encouraging any peer
who is easily influenced by him to separate from him by taking the other youth
outdoors or to an area away from Youth B. If Youth B leaves the cottage, staff are to
follow immediately. If he leaves the campus, staff are to get a vehicle and canvas
the area. If staff cannot locate Youth B in the community, they are to file a police
report and contact the appropriate parties. Upon going AWOL, supervisor or Case
Manager 1 should contact Youth B’s father to notify him that youth has gone AWOL
and may be on his way to his (father’s) house.
Youth B, age 11, was not interviewed on 11/18/21 because he was hospitalized in
critical condition as a result of a car accident in the community that occurred on
11/17/21 while he was AWOL from the facility. On 11/26/21, Youth B was
pronounced dead according to information found in MISACWIS log # 86816507.
Youth C
Youth C, age 11, was admitted to Methodist on 11/9/21. He was not interviewed
jointly on 11/18/21 because he was hospitalized. According to Government Worker
1 he was undergoing surgery for a fractured femur. On 11/19/21, Government
Worker 1 interviewed Youth C at the hospital.
On 12/1/21, I interviewed Youth C at the facility. He presented in a wheelchair.
Youth C’s account of the incident, outlined below, was consistent with what he told
Government Worker 1 on 11/19/21.
Records indicate Youth C went AWOL from Methodist for the first time on 11/16/21
at 5pm. This was his first AWOL, so no special plan was developed to prevent
AWOLs. Asked about that night, he said he left alone and walked west on Six Mile
Road toward Livonia. He did not leave with Youth B or C and was not present to
witness a car being driven off Methodist’s property. Youth C said he returned to the
grounds alone after dark but did not make his presence known to staff. On the
grounds, he noticed Youth A running around outdoors. The two boys talked on the
playscape and decided to walk off-campus again, this time together. The two boys
walked east on Six Mile Road toward Detroit. “We walked for an hour and caught a
bus.” Coincidentally he said Youth B, who had gone AWOL before him, was a
passenger on that same bus. According to Youth C, the three boys exited the bus
together near Youth B’s father’s home. Youth B reportedly went into the house
5

alone and retrieved some car keys. The three boys and a fourth older youth from
the community got into a car. Youth C said he did not know who the car belonged
to. The older boy from the community drove the younger ones around and made a
number of stops throughout the night. Youth C said he fell asleep and woke up
when the car he was riding in crashed.
Staff 1
I interviewed Staff 1 jointly with Government Worker 1 and Chief Impact Officer (CIO
1) present. On the day of the incident, Staff 1 worked in the shelter cottage (Ott)
from 11am to 7pm.
Around 4pm, Staff 1 said Therapist 1 and Youth A exited the cottage and Youth B
exited behind them without permission. Staff 1 followed all of them to the nurse’s
building. Therapist 1 and Youth A went inside the building while Staff 1 remained
outdoors with Youth B. Youth B started pushing on a window of the building.
Therapist 1 attempted to lock the window from the inside. Youth B waited for Youth
A to exit the building. Youth A exited alone, and the two boys began walking
together in the opposite direction of their cottage. Staff 1 followed them encouraging
them to return. The boys refused and continued walking. They reached Six Mile
Road and headed east. Staff 1 followed them until they disappeared from sight.
Staff 1 notified Supervisor 1 that the boys had gone AWOL then she returned to Ott
Cottage. She said Supervisor 1 took a vehicle, looked for the boys and then filed a
missing person’s report with the Redford Police.
Around 4:30pm, Staff 1 was in the cottage and looked outside. She saw Youths A
and B back on the grounds running and hiding. Staff 1 notified her co-workers and
supervisor that she saw the boys back on the grounds, but they were not officially
checked in and were still on AWOL status.
Staff 1 stated she was aware of the individualized safety plans for Youths A and B.
She said she reviewed them with her supervisor and that they were kept in a binder
in Ott Cottage. Prior to Youth B exiting the cottage behind Youth A without
permission, Staff 1 noticed nothing unusual about Youth B’s behavior. While outside
the nurse’s building with Youth B, she said she intervened by asking Youth B why he
wanted to see Youth A so badly and reminded him that he would see Youth B back
to their cottage. Then Staff 1 asked Youth B if there was anything else he wanted to
do to pass the time instead of waiting for Youth A outside the nurse’s building.
“Youth B was fixated on following Youth A and ignored me. He said he wanted to
hurt or shoot staff.”
When Youth A came out of the nurse’s building, Staff 1 recalled Youth B encouraged
Youth A to “come with him.” Then the boys walked away from their cottage and
toward Six Mile Road with Staff 1 following a few feet behind them. Staff 1 offered
6

Youth A options for other activities and asked him why he wanted to leave. “He
said, ‘because Youth B is leaving.’”
At approximately 5pm, Staff 1 said Youth C ran out of Ott Cottage without
permission and refused to come in. “I looked for him on grounds and couldn’t locate
him. I got a vehicle and drove around campus. I scanned one block both ways
down Six Mile and couldn’t find him. I went to Redford Police Department and filed a
report.”
Therapist 1
I interviewed Therapist 1 jointly with Government Worker 1 and CIO 1 present. She
said she took Youth A from Ott cottage to the nurse’s building to clean a scratch on
his neck. “Youth B followed us, and staff (Staff 1) was with him. I was inside
cleaning Youth A’s neck. Youth B was outside opening and closing a window. I
asked him to close the window.” When she finished with Youth A, Therapist 1 said
she released him outside to Staff 1 and stayed inside the building to clean up.
“When I came out, they (Staff 1, Youth A and B) were gone.”
Clinical Director 1
I interviewed Clinical Director 1 jointly with Government Worker 1 and CIO 1 present.
That morning, CD 1 said he parked his 2016 Ford Fusion on the deep end of the
administrative parking lot at the front of the campus. He said he typically leaves his
keys in his car and locks the door from the outside using a digital code. On
11/16/21, CD 1 said he thought he locked his car, but when he went to leave at 5pm,
he could not find it. He looked around and realized it was gone. “I called the
Redford police and reported it stolen (#210023325). The next morning, CD 1 called
the Redford police. “They referred me to the Ferndale Police Department.” The
Ferndale police notified him that his vehicle had been involved in a crime and there
was a “hold” on it.
Neither Youth A nor C reported being inside or outside of the vehicle when it was
driven off Methodist’s property. There are no other known youths or staff who
witnessed the vehicle being driven off the property.
As of 11/16/21, Methodist did not have a policy that specifically mandates staff to
secure their personal vehicles and/or maintain possession of their keys while on duty
at the facility.
Case Manager 1
I interviewed Case Manager 1. He has worked at Methodist for six months. When
Youth B went AWOL on 11/16/21 at 4pm, he said he attempted to reach Youth B’s
father by telephone, but there was no answer. Case Manager 1 could not recall if he
7

left a voice message at that time. The next morning Case Manager 1 said he
successfully reached Youth B’s father by phone.
A case note in MISACWIS indicated Case Manager 1 notified the referral source
(MDHHS) of Youth B’s AWOL on 11/16/21 at 11:41pm.
I reviewed the shelter’s program statement dated 3/24/21 which indicates “the
program provides temporary, short-term residential and diagnostic services to youth
eligible for funding based on MDHHS criteria, males ages 13-17…and serves as a
transitional placement. The staff to resident ratio during waking hours is 1:4 and
1:10 during sleeping hours. Service duration is targeted for 30 days. In some
instances, and with approval from MDHHS, youth will be permitted to remain longer
due to barriers encountered in the referral/placement process (i.e., waiting list,
special needs placement) and/or delays in MDHHS processing. In no case can a
child remain for more than 45 days. If MCHS (Methodist Children’s Home Society)
determines a youth is inappropriate for the program, MCHS will submit a request for
removal to MDHHS…
Youth identified as needing intensive psychiatric care or medically fragile are not
eligible for admission. For example, this would include youth who would require
immediate one-to-one supervision, who are in active psychosis, actively suicidal,
and/or are in need of active psychiatry care. Medically fragile youth would include
youth with a chronic physical condition that requires daily skilled nursing
intervention, need life-sustaining medication and equipment, or would require
specialized equipment that medical facilities have, such as IV poles, feeding pumps,
and medical supplies that exceed what is expected of residential care. MCHS is an
open, non-secure program, located on a campus in a highly populated western
suburb of Detroit. Youth with histories of AWOL may not be appropriate.”
Prior to their placement at Methodist, both Youths A and B had recent psychiatric
hospitalizations and histories of going AWOL from other facilities. Youth A had just
been released from a psychiatric hospital and there was a plan on how staff should
respond to his active hallucinations. This suggests that Youth A may have still
needed “intensive psychiatric care” at the time of his placement and thus, been
inappropriate for Methodist’s shelter.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4109 Program statement.
(1) An institution shall have a current written program
statement which specifically addresses all of the following:
8

(c) Policies and procedures pertaining to admission,
care, and discharge of residents.
ANALYSIS: The agency has written procedures on how staff are to respond
when youths walk off the campus without permission. The staff
followed those procedures. There are no policies mandating
staff to lock their personal vehicles or keep their keys in a
designed place when their vehicles are not in use.
The program statement for Methodist’s shelter indicates “Youth
identified as needing intensive psychiatric care are not eligible
for admission.” Although Youth A may have still required
intensive psychiatric care at the time of his admission to the
shelter, Methodist accepted him aware that he had just spent
two months in a psychiatric hospital.
The shelter program statement also indicates “Youth with
histories of AWOL may not be appropriate.” Youths A and B
both had histories of AWOLing from other facilities prior to their
placement at Methodist’s shelter. Furthermore, at the time of
this incident both boys had already gone AWOL from the facility
at least eleven times.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Repeat Violations
SIR2021C0207027 - intake 8/18/21; CAP approved 10/27/21
SIR2021C0108034 – intake 4/20/21; CAP approved 5/11/21
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4126 Sufficiency of staff.
The licensee shall have a sufficient number of
administrative, supervisory, social service, direct care, and
other staff on duty to perform the prescribed functions
required by these administrative rules and in the agency's
program statement and to provide for the continual needs,
protection, and supervision of residents.
9

ANALYSIS: There is no evidence the facility failed to follow Methodist’s
policy with regard to AWOLs in general. All of the youths were
followed off campus until Staff 1 lost sight of them, and then
missing person’s reports were filed with the Redford Police,
which is consistent with Methodist’s Critical Incident Reporting
policy.
On 11/16/21, safety plans that addressed AWOL behaviors for
Youths A and B were in effect. For Youth A, behavioral cues
specific to AWOL included staff noticing when he was being
influenced by a peer or peers to AWOL, and staff watching him
closely near the back of the cottage as he is known to leave out
the back door. Behavioral cues specific to AWOL for Youth B
were staff noticing when he felt unhappy about being removed
from his father, him asking the whereabouts of peers, and staff
noticing him encouraging peers to AWOL with him.
Based on the interview of Staff 1, she intervened appropriately
after she identified the behavioral cues of both youths that
precede AWOL. Specifically, Youth B was “fixated” on following
Youth A out of the cottage without permission, Youth A is easily
influenced by peers, Youth B preferred to AWOL with others and
Youth B verbally encouraged Youth A to AWOL by asking him to
“come with him.”
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDING:
Methodist’s 10-bed shelter is licensed by the Division of Child Welfare Licensing to
serve males ages 13 – 17. Youths B and C were age 11 when they were admitted
to the shelter, which is noncompliant with the terms of their license.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4104 Rules compliance.
(2) After being licensed, an institution shall, on an ongoing
basis, comply with the act, child caring institution rules,
and terms of the license.
10

ANALYSIS: The licensing terms for Methodist’s short-term shelter program
is males ages 13 – 17. Youths B and C were age 11 when
admitted, which is noncompliant with the terms of their license.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the severity of the violations, once an acceptable corrective action plan is
received, I recommend this facility be placed on a First Provisional license.
